children.name: to say thank you to sb
thank
children.definition: /θæŋk/  to tell someone that you are pleased and grateful for something they havegivenyou ordonefor you:
examples: cám ơn, nói lời cám ơn ai
▪ I spent three hours helping her and she didn’t even thank me.
thank somebody for (doing) something
▪ We must write and thank Cathy for the present.
▪ The Governor publicly thanked the people of Arizona for supporting him during his campaign.
thank somebody profusely
thank someone a lot in a very obvious way
▪ A relieved Mr Maxwell thanked his lawyer profusely.

children.name: say thank you
children.definition: /seɪ ˈθæŋk juː/  to thank someone for what they have done:

children.name: nói lời cám ơn
examples: ▪ I wanted to come round and say thank you in person.

children.name: say thank you to
examples: ▪ This little gift is our way of saying thank you to everyone who worked so hard.

children.name: say thank you for
examples: ▪ Make sure you say thank you for your birthday presents.

children.name: show your appreciation
children.definition: /ˌʃəʊ jɔːr əˌpriːʃiˈeɪʃən/ formalto show someone that you are grateful for something they havedone,by givingthem something or bydoingsomethingspecialfor them:

children.name: tỏ lòng biết ơn ( biếu hay làm gì đặc biệt cho họ )
examples: ▪ He found a special way of showing his appreciation -- dinner at the Ritz.

children.name: show your appreciation for
examples: ▪ We have decided to pay a special bonus to everyone on the staff to show our appreciation for their hard work during the year.

children.name: express your thanks/gratitude
children.definition: /ɪkˌspres jɔːʳ ˈθæŋks, ˈgrættjuːdǁ-tuːd/ formalto say how grateful you are to someone for something they havedone- use this in aspeechor in aletter:
examples: tỏ lòng biết ơn ( trong bài nói truyện hay thư từ )
express your thanks/gratitude for
▪ I should like to express my thanks for all that you have done.
express your thanks/gratitude to
▪ He made a short speech expressing his gratitude to all those who had sent him letters of support.

children.name: acknowledge
children.definition: /əkˈnɒlɪdʒǁ-ˈnɑː-/  to tell peoplepubliclythat someone hasdonesomething to help you and that you are grateful for it:
examples: acknowledgement[uncountable noun]
▪ She has received no official acknowledgement of her contribution to the fund.

children.name: cảm tạ , bày tỏ lòng biết ơn ( công khai )
examples: ▪ In his speech he acknowledged the help his parents gave him at the start of his career.
▪ I did a lot of work on that book. It annoys me that the editor never acknowledged it.

children.name: recognize
children.definition: alsorecogniseBritish /ˈrekəgnaɪz, ˈrekən-/  if acountryor alargeorganizationrecognizes something important that someone hasdonefor them, theyofficiallyandpubliclythank them, bygivingthem something ordoingsomethingspecialfor them:

children.name: ghi nhận, đánh giá cao, tỏ lòng tri ân ( nhà nước ,tổ chức lớn , một cách công khai chính thức )
examples: ▪ The government recognized his bravery in the battle by awarding him the Military Cross.
▪ Her contribution to horticulture was recognized when a new rose was named after her.

children.name: in recognition of sth
children.definition: in recognition of something/ɪn ˌrekəgˈnɪʃən əv something/  if you aregivensomething in recognition of something you have done, it ispubliclygiven to you as a way of thanking you:

children.name: ( được trao tặng gì ) để tỏ lòng tri ân, biết ơn cho
examples: ▪ He was awarded a knighthood in recognition of his work for charity.

children.name: when you feel that you want to thank sb
grateful
children.definition: /ˈgreɪtfəl/  feeling that you want to thank someone, especially because they havedonesomething for you andhelpedyou a lot:
examples: gratefully [adverb]
▪ We gratefully accepted her offer.

children.name: biết ơn
examples: ▪ Dr Shah has received hundreds of letters from grateful patients.

children.name: grateful for
examples: ▪ I’m really grateful for everything you’ve done for me.

children.name: grateful to
examples: ▪ My daughter was rescued safely, and I am very grateful to the firemen.

children.name: gratitude
children.definition: /ˈgrætɪtjuːd, ˈgrætətjuːdǁ-tuːd/  when you feel grateful, especially because someone has been kind to you:
examples: lòng biết ơn
express/show gratitude (for something)
▪ He wrote again, expressing gratitude for the help he had received.
a sense of gratitude
▪ She felt a deep sense of gratitude to the teacher who had encouraged her to go on to university.
in gratitudebecause you are grateful
▪ ‘I’ll take the van back, shall I?’ he asked, and Elise nodded in gratitude.

children.name: thankful
children.definition: /ˈθæŋkfəl/  grateful that someone hasdonesomething, because if they had not done it the situation would have been muchworse:

children.name: biết ơn
examples: ▪ Take what they give you, and be thankful.

children.name: thankful for
examples: ▪ I am always thankful for their enthusiasm and commitment.

children.name: thankful that
examples: ▪ She was thankful that Louise had insisted she travel first class.

children.name: appreciate
children.definition: /əˈpriːʃieɪt/  to be grateful to someone for something that they havedonefor you, because you realize that theydid not have todoit or that they made abig effortto do it for you:

children.name: cảm kích
examples: ▪ We really appreciate everything you’ve done for our daughter.
▪ Alan asked me to tell you how much he appreciated your hospitality when he was in London.

children.name: appreciative
children.definition: /əˈpriːʃətɪv/  showing that you are pleased and grateful for someone’shelporkindness:

children.name: cảm kích
examples: ▪ He wrote a warm, appreciative letter, thanking her for everything she had done.
▪ They weren’t particularly appreciative the last time I helped them. I don’t think I’ll bother again.

children.name: appreciative of
examples: ▪ Our new boss is a real joy to work for. She’s so appreciative of anything you do for her.

children.name: be indebted to
children.definition: /biː ɪnˈdetd tuː/ formalto feel very grateful to someone for something they havegivenyou ordonefor you:

children.name: mang ơn
examples: ▪ We are indebted to the National Archives for permission to print these photographs.

children.name: be greatly/deeply indebted to somebody
examples: ▪ She said that she was greatly indebted to everyone who had supported her campaign.

children.name: owe
children.definition: /əʊ/  if you say you owe someone something, you are grateful because they have helped you to succeed at something or to improve your life, and without their help this might not have been possible:
examples: nợ
owe a lot/a great deal to somebody
▪ I owe a great deal to my publishers, who helped me to finish writing the book.
owe it all/everything to somebody
▪ I owe it all to you. You were the only one who believed in me.
owe somebody a lot/a great deal
▪ ‘I owe my parents a lot,’ he admitted. ‘They worked real hard to put me through college.’
owe a debt of gratitude to somebody
▪ We all owe a debt of gratitude to Mrs Stevenson, who kindly donated the money for the project.

children.name: appreciation
children.definition: /əˌpriːʃiˈeɪʃən/  a feeling that you want to thank someone for their help or service and to show them that you think it was important and valuable:
examples: sự cảm kích, lòng biết ơn
show your appreciation
▪ To show his appreciation of her kindness he sent her some flowers.
in appreciation of somethingin order to show appreciation of
▪ In appreciation of Mr Mainwaring’s years of service, the company presented him with a gold watch.
token of somebody’s appreciationa sign of someone’s appreciation
▪ We’d like you to accept this gift as a small token of our appreciation.

children.name: when sb does not thank you
ungrateful
children.definition: /ʌnˈgreɪtfəl/ someonewho is ungrateful does not thank you when you do something for them, and this makes you annoyed or upset:

children.name: vô ơn, bạc nghĩa
examples: ▪ Our children are so ungrateful - they don’t realize how much we do for them.
▪ I am not prepared to go to jail for that ungrateful woman!

children.name: ingratitude
children.definition: /ɪnˈgrætɪtjuːd, ɪnˈgrætətjuːdǁ-tuːd/  a lack of any feeling of being grateful when someone has given you something or does something for you:
examples: ▪ Such ingratitude! After all I’ve done for him, he treats me like dirt.
▪ They were shocked by her ingratitude -- she didn’t seem to appreciate the trouble they had gone to.

children.name: take sb for granted
children.definition: take somebody for granted/ˌteɪk somebody fəʳ ˈgrɑːntdǁ-ˈgræn-/  to expect someone to help you or do things for you because they always have done, and never thank them or show them that you are grateful:
examples: ▪ Like many married couples, we had started to take each other for granted.
▪ Kids usually take their mother for granted.

children.name: what you say when you thank sb
thank you
children.definition: /ˈθæŋk juː/ say this when you want to thank someone politely:
examples: cám ơn
▪ ‘Would you like to come to dinner with us on Sunday?’ ‘Thank you, I’d love to.’
thank you for
▪ Thank you for a splendid evening. I really enjoyed myself.
▪ Thank you for letting me stay.
thank you very much
▪ It’s lovely. Thank you very much.

children.name: thanks
children.definition: /θæŋks/ spoken use this to thank someone for something they have just done or given you:
examples: cám ơn
▪ ‘Here’s your coffee.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’
thanks for
▪ Thanks for coming. Hope we see you again next year.
thanks to somebodyused in speeches
▪ Thanks to everyone for all the cards and flowers. They really cheered me up.
thanks a lot/a million
▪ ‘Here, let me help you.’ ‘Thanks a lot. That’s great.’

children.name: ta/cheers
children.definition: /tɑː, tʃɪəʳz/ Britishinformalspokensay this when you want to thank someone for something theyhavejustdoneorgivenyou:
examples: cám ơn
▪ ‘Here’s the book you wanted.’ ‘Ta.’
▪ ‘I’ve made you a cup of tea.’ ‘Cheers.’

children.name: that’s very kind of you/good of you
children.definition: /ˌðæts veri ˈkaɪnd əv juː, ˈgʊd əv juː/formalspokensay this when someone has generouslyofferedto do something for you:
examples: bạn tử tế quá
▪ ‘Here, you can have my seat.’ ‘Thank you, that’s very kind of you.’
▪ ‘Would you like me to carry your shopping?’ ‘That’s very good of you!’

children.name: I appreciate it
children.definition: /aɪ əˈpriːʃieɪt ɪt/spokensay this when you want to thank someone who hasdonea lot tohelpyou:

children.name: tôi cảm kích
examples: ▪ Thanks for helping out on a Sunday - I appreciate it.

children.name: I really appreciate it
examples: ▪ I couldn’t have managed without your support and encouragement. I really appreciate it.

children.name: you shouldn’t have
children.definition: /juː ˈʃʊdnt əv/spokensay this when you want to thank someone who hasgivenyou something, especially somethingexpensive:

children.name: Bạn không cần làm vậy
examples: ▪ What a beautiful ring! Oh Mike, you shouldn’t have!

children.name: you’ve saved my life
children.definition: /juːv ˌseɪvd maɪ ˈlaɪf/spokenuse this to thank someone who has got you out of a difficult situation, or solved a problem for you:

children.name: bạn đã cứu đời tôi
examples: ▪ You’ve saved my life, Jim! Thank goodness you were here.

children.name: I’d like to thank
children.definition: /aɪd ˌlaɪk tə ˈθæŋk/spokenuse this to thank someone in aformalspeech:

children.name: Tối muốn cám ơn đến
examples: ▪ I would like to thank everyone who helped at the school fair.

children.name: I’d like to thank somebody for (doing) something
examples: ▪ I’d like to thank Betty and Jim for organizing this wonderful party.

children.name: many thanks
children.definition: /ˌmeni ˈθæŋks/ use this to thank someone, especially whenwritingaletter:

children.name: cám ơn rất nhiều ( trong thư )
examples: ▪ We received the pictures on Wednesday. Many thanks.

children.name: many thanks for
examples: ▪ Many thanks for your letter of the other day.

children.name: st that you say or do to thank sb
thanks
children.definition: /θæŋks/  what you say or do to thank someone:
examples: ▪ He won’t get any thanks from them for being so honest.

children.name: thanks for
examples: ▪ Please accept this bottle of champagne as our thanks for organizing the seminar.

children.name: letter/message etc of thanksexpressing thanks
examples: ▪ He wrote me a short letter of thanks.

children.name: without a word of thankswithout saying thank you
examples: ▪ She got up and left without a word of thanks.

children.name: a vote of thanksa formal, public expression of thanks, especially at a meeting
examples: ▪ I’d like to propose a vote of thanks to Sandra for organizing the whole evening.

children.name: thank-you letter/note
children.definition: /ˈθæŋk juː ˌletəʳ, ˌnəʊt/  a letter that you send to someone to thank them, for example when they have given you a present or when you have stayed at their house:
examples: ▪ We spent three days after the wedding writing thank-you letters for all the presents we’d had.

children.name: acknowledgements
children.definition: /əkˈnɒlɪdʒməntsǁ-ˈnɑː-/  a note at the end or beginning of a book, article etc, in which the writer thanks all the people who helped him or her to produce it:
examples: ▪ In the acknowledgements the authors thanked everyone who’d contributed to the book.
▪ Her book was based on her ex-husband’s letters and yet his name did not even appear in the acknowledgements.

children.name: what you say to sb when they thank you
don’t mention it
children.definition: /ˌdəʊnt ˈmenʃən ɪt/ spoken:
examples: ▪ ‘Thanks for the lift!’ ‘Oh, don’t mention it!’

children.name: that’s all right/that’s OK
children.definition: /ˌðæts ɔːl ˈraɪt, ˌðæts əʊˈkeɪ/ informal spoken:
examples: ▪ ‘Thank you so much for looking after the children.’ ‘That’s all right. I enjoyed having them.’

children.name: you’re welcome
children.definition: /jɔːʳ ˈwelkəm/ especially American, spoken:
examples: ▪ ‘Thanks a lot.’ ‘You’re welcome!’

children.name: my pleasure/not at all
children.definition: /ˌmaɪ ˈpleʒəʳ, ˌnɒt ət ˈɔːl/ formal spoken:

children.name: ▪ ‘It was very good of you to sing for us at such short notice.’ ‘My pleasure!’
examples: ▪ ‘Thanks for dinner’ ‘Not at all - I enjoyed it’.

children.name: think nothing of it/it was nothing
children.definition: /θɪŋk ˌnʌθɪŋ ˈɒv ɪt, ɪt wəz ˈnʌθɪŋ/ spoken say this when someone has thanked you a lot for something you have done because they think it was very difficult for you to do:
examples: ▪ ‘You shouldn’t have gone to so much trouble, you know!’ ‘Oh, think nothing of it.’
▪ ‘Thank you for all your help. I couldn’t have done it without you.’ ‘Don’t mention it. It was nothing.’

children.name: no problem
children.definition: /ˌnəʊ ˈprɒbləmǁ-ˈprɑːb-/ informal spoken say this to show that what someone has thanked you for was really a very easy thing for you to do:
examples: ▪ ‘Thank you for coming all the way out here.’ ‘No problem, lady.’

children.name: sure
children.definition: /ʃʊəʳ/ American spoken used as a reply to someone who has thanked you for something:
examples: ▪ ‘Thanks for the ride.’ ‘Sure, no problem.’

children.name: thanks
children.definition: /θæŋks/  what you say or do to thank someone:

children.name: lời cám ơn, lòng cám ơn
examples: ▪ He won’t get any thanks from them for being so honest.

children.name: thanks for
examples: ▪ Please accept this bottle of champagne as our thanks for organizing the seminar.

children.name: letter/message etc of thanksexpressing thanks
examples: ▪ He wrote me a short letter of thanks.

children.name: without a word of thankswithout saying thank you
examples: ▪ She got up and left without a word of thanks.

children.name: a vote of thanksa formal, public expression of thanks, especially at a meeting : một tràng vỗ tay hoan hô
examples: ▪ I’d like to propose a vote of thanks to Sandra for organizing the whole evening.

children.name: thank-you letter
children.definition: /note/ˈθæŋk juː ˌletəʳ, ˌnəʊt/  a letter that you send to someone to thank them, for example when they have given you a present or when you have stayed at their house:
examples: ▪ We spent three days after the wedding writing thank-you letters for all the presents we’d had.
